name: Host and Process Metrics - otel + telegraf
description: The Sumo Logic App for Host and Process Metrics allows you to monitor the performance and resource utilization of hosts and processes that your mission critical applications are dependent upon. Preconfigured dashboards provide insight into CPU, memory, network, file descriptors, page faults and TCP connectors. This app uses Telegraf, an open source, plugin-based collector for collection of both host and process metrics data.

children.name: Host Metrics - CPU
children.description: The Host Metrics - CPU dashboard provides a detailed analysis based on CPU metrics.
children.title: Host Metrics - CPU

queries.queryString: _sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric     host.name={{host.name}} cpu=cpu-total  metric=host_cpu field=usage_user | avg by host.name

_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric     host.name={{host.name}} cpu=cpu-total  metric=host_cpu field=usage_idle   | avg

panels.text:
### CPU Involuntary Wait Time (Steal)
Steal time is the percentage of time the virtual machine process is waiting on the physical CPU for its CPU time. If you deploy to a virtualized environment (for example, Amazon EC2), and involuntary wait is high, performance can suffer significantly. If CPU steal is > 10%, a noisy neighbor could be affecting the resource utilization or a spot instance may be out of credits.


#### Causes of High Involuntary Wait Time (Steal)
* The VM needs more CPU resources.
* The physical server has been over-sold and virtual machines are aggressively competing for CPU resources.

queries.queryString: _sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric     host.name={{host.name}} cpu=cpu-total  metric=host_cpu field=(usage_user OR usage_system OR usage_iowait OR usage_steal OR usage_softirq OR usage_irq OR usage_nice) | sum by host.name | outlier
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric     host.name={{host.name}} cpu=cpu-total  metric=host_cpu field=usage_system | avg by host.name
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric     host.name={{host.name}}  metric=procstat field=cpu_usage  | avg by process.executable.name

_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}}  cpu=cpu-total  metric=host_cpu field=(usage_user OR usage_system OR usage_iowait OR usage_steal OR usage_softirq OR usage_irq OR usage_nice) | sum by host.name

panels.text:
#### CPU Load Vs CPU Usage
 - CPU Usage is the percentage of time the CPU is working while CPU Load measures how many programs are using or waiting for a processor core.  
 - How are they different? - You can have a high load with nearly 0% CPU utilization (such as when you have a lot of IO data stuck in a wait state) and you can have a load of 1 and 100% CPU, when you have a single threaded process running full time.
 -  How are they related? - A 4 core CPU with hyperthreading (8 virtual cores) all at 100% for 1 minute would contribute 8 to the 1 minute load average.

### CPU I/O Wait Time
I/O wait is the percentage of time that CPUs were idle during which the system had pending disk I/O requests.

#### Causes
* Storage devices that have less throughput are not able to keep up with CPU performance.
* Unoptimized application code and/or database queries lead to high disk reads/writes.
* Not having enough free memory leads to swapping and paging to disk.

panels.title: Untitled
panels.text:
* Disk I/O Active Operations - This value counts the number of I/O requests that have been issued to the device driver but have not yet completed. It does not include I/O requests that are in the queue but not yet issued to the device driver.

*  Following panels are not available for Windows
  - Free Inodes
  - Active Disk I/O Operations

_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}} metric=host_mem field=free | sum by host.name

#A -#B -#C along host.name
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}} metric=host_mem field=available_percent  | sum by host.name
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}} metric=host_mem field=free  | sum by host.name

panels.title: Available and Free Memory
panels.text:
Available memory is the amount of memory available to a new process or to existing processes and includes free and buffer/cache memory.

Free memory is the amount of memory not being used (for other purposes likee caching) and is readily available.

queries.queryString: _sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}} metric=host_mem field=swap_free | sum by host.name
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   metric=host_mem field=swap_total | sum by host.name
(#B - #A)*100/#B along host.name | outlier
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   metric=win_swap  field=percent_usage | avg by host.name
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}} metric=host_mem field=used_percent | sum by host.name
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}} metric=host_mem field=used_percent | sum by host.name | outlier

panels.title: Buffers vs Cached vs Swap Cached
panels.text:
* Buffer Cache Memory: Memory in the buffer cache that holds temporary storage for raw disk blocks. 
* Cache Memory: Memory in the page cache (Includes Disk Cache and Shared Memory)
* Swap Cached Memory: Memory present within main memory, but also in the swapfile. If memory is needed, this area does not need to be swapped out again because it is already in the swapfile. This saves I/O and increases performance if the machine runs out of memory.

queries.queryString: _sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}} metric=host_mem field=swap_cached  | sum by host.name
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}} metric=host_mem field=buffered  | sum by host.name
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}} metric=host_mem field=cached   | sum by host.name

panels.title: Swapping
panels.text:
* Do you need swap even if you have enough RAM? - Linux starts swapping before the RAM is filled up. This is done to improve performance (for the disk cache) and responsiveness (swapping pages out when the system is idle).

* How to control when to swap? - In Linux, VM swapiness controls the relative weight given to swapping out of runtime memory, as opposed to dropping memory pages from the system page cache
.
* Effects - Swapping slows down the system and high frequency of swap I/O is a good indicator of low memory.

queries.queryString: _sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric     host.name={{host.name}}  field=memory_usage metric=procstat | avg by host.name, process.executable.name

panels.text:
Following panels are not available for Windows
* Total free memory
* Buffer / Cached /  Swap Cached

panels.title: High CPU Load Causes
panels.text:
* The host does not have the required CPU resources to meet the demand
* There may be too many virtual CPUs relative to the number of physical processor cores
* There may be an IO storage or networking operation that places the CPU in a wait state
* The Guest OS generates too much load for the CPU

panels.title: Major vs Minor Page Faults
panels.text:
* A minor page fault indicates the page is in memory but not allocated to the requesting process or not marked as present in the memory management unit.
* A major page fault occurs because of the absence of the required page from the RAM and bringing it in costs heavy penalty in terms of CPU cycles. If it's value is high compare it with swap in/swap out activity to confirm thrashing (high paging activity).

panels.title: Resident Set vs Virtual Memory
panels.text:
Virtual Memory Size is the memory a process has available for its execution. It includes all memory that the process can access, including memory that is swapped out, memory that is allocated, but not used, and memory from shared libraries.

Resident Set Size is the memory allocated to that process and is in RAM. It includes all stack and heap memory but excludes memory that is swapped out . It does include memory from shared libraries as long as the pages from those libraries are actually in memory. 

Use the RSS Memory panel for troubleshooting memory leaks.

* Following panels are not available for windows
 - Major Page Faults
 - Signals Pending
 - File Descriptors
 - InVoluntary Context Switches

queries.queryString: _sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   metric=procstat field=cpu_usage host.name={{host.name}}  process.executable.name={{process.executable.name}}  | max by host.name, process.executable.name | topk (10, max)

_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   metric=procstat field=memory_usage host.name={{host.name}}  process.executable.name={{process.executable.name}}  | max by host.name, process.executable.name | topk (10, max)

_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   metric=procstat field=cpu_usage host.name={{host.name}}  process.executable.name={{process.executable.name}} | avg by host.name, process.executable.name | filter avg > 65 |  topk(10, avg)

_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   metric=procstat field=memory_usage host.name={{host.name}}  process.executable.name={{process.executable.name}} | avg by host.name, process.executable.name | filter avg > 65 |  topk(10, avg)

_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   metric=procstat field=created_at host.name={{host.name}} process.executable.name={{process.executable.name}} | min by process.executable.name, host.name | bottomk(10, max)
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   metric=procstat field=created_at host.name={{host.name}} process.executable.name={{process.executable.name}} user=* | count by user | topk(10, latest)

panels.title: Processes with Multiple Open File Descriptors

queries.queryString: _sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   metric=procstat field=num_fds host.name={{host.name}}  process.executable.name={{process.executable.name}} | avg by host.name, process.executable.name | filter latest > 1 |  topk(10, latest)

_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   metric=procstat (field=read_count or field=write_count) AND host.name={{host.name}}  process.executable.name={{process.executable.name}} | sum by host.name, process.executable.name | filter sum > 65 |  topk(10, sum)

_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   metric=procstat field=num_threads host.name={{host.name}} process.executable.name={{process.executable.name}} | max by process.executable.name, host.name | topk(10, max)

children.name: Process Metrics - Trends
children.description: The Process Metrics - Trend dashboard gives you insight about the state of your processes over time.
children.title: Process Metrics - Trends

queries.queryString: _sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}}  metric=processes field=total | sum by host.name | outlier
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric    metric=processes host.name={{host.name}}   field=total_threads | sum by host.name | outlier
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}}  metric=processes  field=dead
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}}    metric=processes field=zombies

queries.queryString: _sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}}  metric=processes  AND (field=running OR field=stopped OR field=sleeping OR field=blocked OR field=dead OR field=wait OR field=idle OR field=paging) | avg by field
_sourceCategory=anema/hostAndProcess/metric   host.name={{host.name}}   metric=processes field=total | avg by field

panels.title: Daemons vs Zombie vs Orphan  Processes
panels.text:
* Daemons are processes that run unattended in background. Daemons are usually started when the system starts, and they run until the system stops.
* Zombie processes are dead processes that is no longer executing but is still recognized in the process table and continues to exist until the parent process dies or the system shuts down. Processes that stay as zombies for a long time are generally caused because of errors and can needlessly occupy entries in the process table entry, which if you have too many entries, you won't be able to create a new process. For Linux "defunct" and "zombie" processes are the same.
* An orphan process is a process that is still executing, but whose parent has died and therefore gets adopted by the init process.
This dashboard does not lit up for windows hosts
